title: bst-nth
description: Write a function `bst-nth` that takes a binary search tree and a non-negative integer n, and returns the element at index n in the sorted order of the tree (inorder traversal). The smallest element is at index 0. If n is out of bounds, return false.

examples.explanation: Single node tree, index 0 returns the element
Inorder traversal gives (2 5 8), so index 1 is 5
Index 3 is out of bounds for a 3-element tree

starterCode:
(define-struct node (left right key))

(define (bst-nth t n))

(bst-nth empty 0)
(bst-nth (make-node empty empty 5) 0)
(bst-nth (make-node (make-node empty empty 2) (make-node empty empty 8) 5) 1)
(bst-nth (make-node (make-node empty empty 2) (make-node empty empty 8) 5) 3)
hiddenCases: (check-expect (bst-nth (make-node (make-node (make-node empty empty 1) (make-node empty empty 3) 2) (make-node (make-node empty empty 6) (make-node empty empty 8) 7) 5) 0) 1)
(check-expect (bst-nth (make-node (make-node (make-node empty empty 1) (make-node empty empty 3) 2) (make-node (make-node empty empty 6) (make-node empty empty 8) 7) 5) 4) 6)
(check-expect (bst-nth (make-node (make-node (make-node empty empty 1) (make-node empty empty 3) 2) (make-node (make-node empty empty 6) (make-node empty empty 8) 7) 5) 7) false)
(check-expect (bst-nth (make-node (make-node (make-node (make-node empty empty 1) empty 3) empty 7) (make-node empty (make-node empty empty 15) 12) 10) 5) 15)
